 3D-printing them)

>  
>  
>  
>    
> 
> Jeff, your paper is a great explorations of the pro=
perties of the CPPN
> encoding in 3D. 

Thanks Ken. I'm glad you liked it.
=

>  I do have a couple thoughts on the target-based
> experiment:
> 
> Firs=
t, the evolved results from the target-based runs all look really
> interes=
ting.  They do look like they were carved with a lathe, which is
> kind of =
surprising.  Maybe you should seek funding from a
> banister-design company=
!
That would be hilarious. The lathe property makes sense, though, if you
t=
hink of what happens with a lathe: you subtract material along two
dimensio=
ns while keeping radial symmetry around the rotating axis. I assume
the CPP=
N is using the distance from center to come up with a way to do that,
which=
 is helpful for this target.

> 
> In any case, regarding the connection to=
 my paper with Brian, we
> observed basically two phenomena:  One is that i=
f the target is
> sufficiently complex, it simply cannot be reached.  Howev=
er, when the
> targets were simple enough, in fact they could be reproduced=
 reliably.
> Yet the problem when the targets actually were reproduced well=
 was that
> their CPPNs were two or three times as large as the CPPN that g=
enerated
> the original target.  So our message was not simply that you can=
't reach
> targets, but that even when you do, you pay a price with inelega=
nt
> representation complexity.  Your case appears somewhere in the middle:=

> the attempts do not look bad, although they are not perfect
> reproducti=
ons either.

I agree. It's a shame that I can't answer the question of whet=
her the
target-based CPPNs are unnecessarily complex/inelegant, because I d=
on't have
non-target CPPNs that produce the target. It would not be hard, h=
owever, to
conduct the same experiment you did in 2D in 3D.

> 
> 
> I am g=
uessing that the target you chose is thus sort of on the
> borderline of co=
mplexity that is almost reproducible, like the "Eye"
> target in our paper.=
  What would be interesting would be to see the CPPN
> structures of the be=
st approximations to see whether they are encoding
> the fundamental concep=
t or stringing it together inefficiently.  I know
> you said that the morph=
ologies themselves don't look "piecemeal," but
> they could still be constr=
ucted in a piecewise fashion mathematically.
> For example, figure 8i has s=
ome subtle ridges suggestive of unnecessary
> underlying complexity.
That w=
ould be cool to see. I wish I could drop these genomes into a DNA
Viewer li=
ke Picbreeder has. Maybe we should make one for EndlessForms.com.
:-)

But =
8i does seem to be the exception, the other shapes seem to be pretty
regula=
r. 

> 
> Another interesting factor is the number of evaluations to get wi=
thin
> 90%.  It varies across your treatments, but 30,000 evaluations or so=

> looks like a reasonable expectation with your system.   With a
> populat=
ion of 15 in Picbreeder, that would be 2,000 generations, which
> is a real=
ly large number for the complexity of the target object (you
> can also see=
 objects of similar complexity in EndlessForms from 10 or 20
> generations)=
.  So I think your experiment is pretty consistent with ours
> overall, tho=
ugh it wasn't geared at making the same point.

I generally agree with you.=
 The main question we don't know is how hard this
sphere target is on the s=
cale explored in your paper with Brian.

For example, just playing around a=
 bit on EndlessForms I found this object
in a few generations, and it is pr=
etty close to the sphere target. That
suggests similar results to your pape=
r, where humans can find things quickly
that target-based evolution struggl=
es with.

http://endlessforms.com/o/7978

Sadly, it predates our ancestor v=
iew, so we can't see the exact historical
path, but my guess is that some i=
ntermediate stages looked nothing like the
final target. If anyone else evo=
lves something like the sphere target,
please publish it and let us know.

=
Thanks for your answer Ken.

Jeff

> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@...=
m <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> , Jeff Clune
> <jeffclune@...> wrote:
>> =
>
>> > Hello everyone-
>> >
>> > Hod Lipson and I have a new publication on=
 evolving 3D morphologies
> with
>> > CPPNs, which explains the algorithm b=
ehind EndlessForms.com.
>> >
>> > PDF:  http://goo.gl/HRXLD
>> >
>> > Most =
of you will at least enjoy quickly scanning the figures to see
> the
>> > e=
volved shapes, which are higher resolution and different than those
> on
>>=
 > EndlessForms.com.  You can also see a picture of the evolved shapes 3D
>=
> > printed.
>> >
>> > The diversity of shapes I was able to discover just =
playing with the
> system
>> > myself for a few hours is pretty incredible,=
 which is a testament to
> Ken's
>> > CPPN encoding. Additionally, I ran te=
sts with and without recurrence
> in the
>> > CPPN genome, and with differe=
nt inputs to the CPPN, and you can see
> the
>> > difference those choices =
make in the resultant objects. For example,
> with
>> > CPPN recurrence, th=
e shapes often look more fractal. I believe (but
> please
>> > correct me i=
f I am wrong) that this is the first publication with a
> test of
>> > CPPN=
s with and without recurrence.
>> >
>> > FInally, I conducted target-based =
evolution by evolving CPPNs to match
> a
>> > goal object. I'd be intereste=
d to hear if you think the goal was
> reached,
>> > and how to interpret th=
ese results in light of Brian Woolley & Ken
> Stanley's
>> > paper on CPPNs=
 not being able to reach target 2D objectives.
>> >
>> > What I like best a=
bout being able to evolve 3D objects is learning how
> the
>> > CPPN search=
 space works: mutations frequently produce very sensible
>> > variation. Fo=
r example, the two 3D printed elephants in figure one are
>> > brothers, an=
d are close relatives of the three elephant-looking things
> in
>> > figure=
 4 (b2-4). It's nice to see mutations have such smooth, sensible
>> > effec=
ts, instead of creating wildly different objects.
>> >
>> > As always, plea=
se let me know your thoughts and questions.
>> >
>> > Best regards,
>> > Je=
ff Clune
>> >
>> > Postdoctoral Fellow
>> > Hod Lipson's Creative Machines =
Laboratory
>> > Cornell University
>> > jeffclune@...
>> > www.msu.edu/~jcl=
une
>> >
> 
>  
>    
> 
>  



--B_3391947419_49000300

duced reliably. <br>Yet the problem when the targets actually were reproduc=

N that generated<br>the original target.  So our message was not simply tha=
t you can't reach<br>
targets, but that even when you do, you pay a price w=
ith inelegant<br>
representation complexity.  Your case appears somewhere i=
n the middle:<br>
the attempts do not look bad, although they are not perfe=
ct<br>
reproductions either.</p></div></div></div></div></div></blockquote>=

son and I have a new publication on evolving 3D morphologies<br>

gt; CPPNs, which explains the algorithm behind EndlessForms.com.<br>

r>

gt;<br>

o see<br>

erent than those<br>

ity of shapes I was able to discover just playing with the<br>
system<br>
&=
gt; myself for a few hours is pretty incredible, which is a testament to<br=
>
Ken's<br>
> CPPN encoding. Additionally, I ran tests with and without =
recurrence<br>
in the<br>
> CPPN genome, and with different inputs to th=
e CPPN, and you can see<br>
the<br>
> difference those choices make in t=
he resultant objects. For example,<br>
with<br>

hapes often look more fractal. I believe (but<br>
please<br>
> correct m=
e if I am wrong) that this is the first publication with a<br>
test of<br>
=

><br>

ted target-based evolution by evolving CPPNs to match<br>
a<br>

bject. I'd be interested to hear if you think the goal was<br>
